TextBlock.Text: PYE: What a fascinating object! The core seems to repel us, somehow!
YARROW: Perhaps the pink liquid is pushing us up?
CLARY: I somehow doubt that. Normal uplift forces would not be enough to compensate for our weight.
POKE: Hypothesis: The core is composed of a powerful magnet, which is repelling us!
CLARY: That's a silly idea. We aren't charged, the liquid around it isn't charged, and not to mention that such an object would lose its charge over time.
PYE: Ah, what if it's from radiation pressure from all the photons emitted by the core?
POKE: It would require a truly enormous amount of luminosity to generate enough radiation pressure to repel us... but it would explain core's unusual brightness.
YARROW: But then why aren't the liquid around it also blown away by this pressure?
PYE: I'm not sure. Perhaps it has a high adhesive force with whatever material the core is made of?
YARROW: And perhaps the innermost layer of liquid was, somehow, travelling towards the core at a high enough velocity to overcome to radiation pressure and stick to it in the first place!
CLARY: Hmm.. how could it generate such intense luminosity?
POKE: Perhaps it's a white dwarf - the remains of an extinguished star. Such bodies still retain some of the original star's thermal energy with which it can emit light.
CLARY: That's still not enough... there must be something within its core to continually power it.
PYE: The path forward is clear then - let's construct a landing pad on the core, so we can investigate this object further!
